questions.text: A patient presented with complaint of a jaw swelling. His tissue was found to have the presence of t (8;14). The histopathological appearance of the bone marrow aspirate tissue is given in the image. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkitt lymphoma 

 

The presence of a translocation t(8;14) is characteristic of Burkitt’s lymphoma. The same is confirmed by the tumor cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli.

 

Direct lines from Robbins.. - ”When the bone marrow is involved, aspirates reveal tumor cells with slightly clumped nuclear chromatin, two to five distinct nucleoli, and royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular lymphoma: Characterized by t(14;18) translocation and involves BCL2 gene, not typically presenting with jaw swelling.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Does not involve t(8;14) translocation and has different histopathological features.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Plasma cell neoplasm, typically presents with bone pain, anemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia, not with t(8;14) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt lymphoma is identified by the presence of the t(8;14) translocation and histopathological features including cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and distinct nucleoli. It commonly presents with jaw or abdominal tumors and requires prompt recognition and treatment due to its aggressive nature.

questions.text: Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta from the fetus through? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Umbilical artery

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal circulation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Umbilical vein: Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, not deoxygenated blood.

 

Option C. Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta in fetal circulation, bypassing the lungs. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC, allowing oxygenated blood to bypass the liver. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deoxygenated blood exits the fetus through the umbilical arteries, which return it to the placenta.

 

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant lady presents with fever and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotics + Heparin

 

Explanation:

 

Antibiotics + heparin:

 

Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) is a rare postpartum infective complication characterized by persistent high-grade fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. It typically occurs after delivery or abortion and is often seen in women with risk factors like cesarean section, prolonged labor, or pelvic infection.

 

The fever in SPT is caused by a septic thrombus in the pelvic veins—most commonly the ovarian vein—that harbors bacteria and incites a sustained inflammatory response. Since antibiotics alone cannot fully penetrate the infected thrombus, the addition of anticoagulation (usually low molecular weight heparin) is essential. Heparin helps in lysing the thrombus, preventing further propagation and improving antibiotic penetration.

 

Clinical improvement is usually seen within 48–72 hours of initiating combined therapy with antibiotics and heparin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop antibiotics and start heparin:  Incorrect because infection is still present—antibiotics are needed to control the infective component.  Stopping antibiotics would worsen sepsis.

 

Option C. Surgical embolectomy:  Too invasive and not first-line.  Reserved for rare cases with septic emboli or failure to respond to medical management.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Not indicated unless there’s uncontrolled pelvic infection not responding to medical therapy or associated endomyometritis with uterine necrosis.  SPT is usually confined to pelvic veins, not requiring removal of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2951, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mediastinum

 

Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly seen in mediastinum.

 

Extragonadal germinal cell tumors (EGGCTs) are rare tumors that predominantly affect young males.

 

These tumors are particularly significant because they mimic the normal germ cell tumors but appear in unusual locations, making them a critical diagnostic challenge. The prevalence of EGGCTs in the mediastinum indicates the importance of considering this location when evaluating patients with symptoms suggestive of germ cell tumors but without testicular or ovarian masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: While EGGCTs can occur here, they represent only about 5% of cases.

 

Option B. Retroperitoneum: This site accounts for 30-40% of EGGCT cases, making it the second most common site.

 

Option C. Sacrococcygeal region: This is the least common site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of extragonadal germ cell tumor –

 

  • Mediastinum (50-70%)
  • Retroperitoneum (30-40%)
  • Pineal gland (5%)
  • Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

choices.text: Hemophilia A
Hemophilia B
Von Willebrand disease

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is characterized by prolonged bleeding time due to a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a critical protein in platelet adhesion and aggregation processes. Prolonged APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) is also seen in this condition because VWF stabilizes factor VIII, an essential clotting factor. The deficiency or dysfunction of VWF thus impacts both primary hemostasis (bleeding time) and secondary hemostasis (APTT).

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Hemophilia A and B. Hemophilia B: These conditions involve deficiencies in clotting factors VIII and IX, respectively, which primarily affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway but not typically the bleeding time.

 

Option D. Hemophilia C: Known as a deficiency in factor XI, this condition also typically affects the intrinsic pathway and APTT but not bleeding time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low EF

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

An Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (AICD) is used for the prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with various cardiac conditions that predispose them to life-threatening arrhythmias. The indications include:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: A genetic disorder that can lead to dangerous ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation (VF): A life-threatening heart rhythm that results in rapid, inadequate heartbeats.

 

Option C. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with low ejection fraction (EF): After a myocardial infarction, patients with significantly reduced EF are at higher risk for ventricular arrhythmias.

 

The device is particularly beneficial in patients with structural heart disease, prior myocardial infarction, and those who have experienced syncope due to undetermined reasons but are found to have inducible ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation during electrophysiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class I Indications for AICD implantation:

 

  1. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  2. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  3. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 30% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI.
  4. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 40% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and inducible VT/VF on EP study (EPS).
  5. Syncope of unknown etiology and inducible VT/ VF on EPS.
  6. Sustained VT in the presence of structural heart disease.
  7. Brugada syndrome.
  8. HCM with > 1 risk factor for SCD.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Ventricular Arrhythmias/Chapter 252

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

 

This is the recovery position, indicated in post-op patients who are awake or drowsy or unconscious with pulse and breathing present to prevent aspiration of any secretions or vomit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent: Means the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate resuscitation measures.

 

Option B. Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent: This is respiratory arrest and rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to maintain breathing of patient.

 

Option D. Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present: This seems very theoretical because with a lack of circulation, breathing isn’t feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient who has a pulse and is breathing to prevent aspiration and maintain airway patency.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has malaise for 2 weeks. His investigations revealed an elevated creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. His blood tests also showed the presence of HBs antigen. A renal biopsy was performed which demonstrated spike and dome on special staining. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous glomerulopathy

 

The elderly patient is having a renal dysfunction. The presence of a ‘spike and dome’ pattern on special staining (silver staining) is suggestive of immune complex deposition. This is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy. The diagnosis isd also supported by the presence of HBs antigen as the hepatitis B infection is characteristically associated with development of membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children and does not show the spike and dome pattern on biopsy. No change on light microscopy; Electron microscopy shows podocyte effacement

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli, not associated with the spike and dome pattern.

 

Option D. Renal amyloidosis: Demonstrates amyloid deposits that can be identified with Congo red staining and apple-green birefringence under polarized light, not a spike and dome pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous glomerulopathy, associated with hepatitis B infection, presents with nephrotic syndrome and demonstrates a characteristic spike and dome pattern on renal biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Histology: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ptosis

 

  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy is caused by hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change.
  • The arrangement of the fibers in the third cranial nerve is such that the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are superficial and often spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury.
  • Pupillary dysfunction is not commonly present in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • The levator palpebrae superiors and most of the oculomotor muscles, except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique, are damaged in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia.

 

APPLIED ANATOMY OF PUPILLOMOTOR NERVE FIBRES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proptosis: Protrusion of the eye, not typically associated with diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Pseudoptosis: False appearance of ptosis, not related to actual muscle dysfunction.

 

Option D. Pupillary dysfunction: Although part of the oculomotor nerve's function, it is usually spared in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy due to the peripheral location of the pupillary fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

 

The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

 

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

 

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/uL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test): This test is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of antibodies to Treponema pallidum and is used to confirm a syphilis infection but is not specific for neurosyphilis as it can be positive due to past or present infection anywhere in the body.

 

Option C. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test): Similar to VDRL, used as a screening test for syphilis based on the detection of non-treponemal antibodies indicative of an active infection, but not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): This is an older, highly specific test that is not commonly used today.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

 

The saccule develops from pars inferior.

 

Development of internal ear:

 

  • Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicles or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of the phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Saculus anterior - Not a term typically associated with the development of the ear's structures.

 

Option B. Saculus posterior - Similarly, this is not a recognized term in the developmental anatomy of the ear.

 

Option C. Pars superior - Incorrect, as this part contributes to the development of the semicircular canals and utricle, not the saccule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 13

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

questions.text: Which among the following according to the latest guidelines is NOT an indication to IE prophylaxis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atrial Septal Defect

 

According to the latest guidelines, there are specific indications for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis to prevent infection in high-risk patients. These indications include:

 

  1. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Patients with a history of infective endocarditis are at increased risk for recurrence and hence, are recommended for prophylaxis.
  2. Prosthetic Valves: Patients with prosthetic heart valves, especially mechanical valves, are susceptible to infections and require prophylaxis.
  3. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Those who have undergone cardiac transplant and have developed valvulopathy are also indicated for IE prophylaxis.
  4. Congenital Heart Disease: This includes any unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, repaired congenital heart disease with prosthetic material for the first six months post-repair, or repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects.

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not listed among these high-risk conditions. ASD, especially without significant gradient across the atria or significant shunting, has a very low risk of causing infective endocarditis. Therefore, ASD does not fit into the current guidelines for IE prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prior Infective Endocarditis: Prior infective endocarditis significantly increases the risk of recurrent infection, thus requiring IE prophylaxis as per the guidelines.

 

Option C. Unrepaired Cyanotic Congenital Heart Disease: Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease is a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis, necessitating prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Cardiac Transplant with Valvulopathy: Patients who have undergone a cardiac transplant and have valvulopathy are at increased risk for infection and are indicated for IE prophylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis according to the latest guidelines, whereas prior infective endocarditis, prosthetic valves, cardiac transplant with valvulopathy, and certain congenital heart diseases are key indications.

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

 

Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm: True. Generally, surgery (either open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic male patients when the AAA reaches a diameter of 5.5 cm (55mm) or greater. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the diameter surpasses this threshold, so this is the currently accepted cutoff for intervention in many guidelines.

 

Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

 

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size <55mm.

 

Other Options:

 

The size of an AAA determines the risk of rupture, and this risk informs the decision for surgical intervention.

 

Option A. Urgent endovascular aneurysm repair: Not necessarily true for a 40mm AAA. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a less invasive method than open surgery, but it is not typically done urgently for aneurysms of this size unless they are symptomatic or rapidly increasing in size.

 

Option C. Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery: Not true for a 40mm AAA. As the aneurysm is still below the general threshold for surgical intervention, there's no need for urgent operation unless there are other complicating factors (e.g., rapid growth or symptoms).

 

Option D. Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >70mm: Not true. Waiting for an AAA to reach 70mm before considering surgery would expose the patient to a very high risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms—dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline (dementia)—represent the classic triad of pellagra, which is associated with niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is commonly summarized as the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. In severe untreated cases, it can lead to a fourth "D," which is death. Niacin deficiency can occur due to poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or conditions that affect tryptophan metabolism, such as Hartnup disease and carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi, which manifests as dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy) or wet beriberi (cardiac failure). It can also cause Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis, particularly in alcoholics, but it does not cause dermatitis or diarrhea.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, depression, and seizures. It does not typically cause the 3D symptoms seen in pellagra unless it indirectly leads to niacin deficiency by impairing tryptophan metabolism.

 

Option D. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency primarily affects vision, immune function, and skin health, causing conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia, but it does not cause diarrhea or cognitive decline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

choices.text: β-2 microglobulin
Calcium levels
Serum creatinine

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) β-2 microglobulin

 

β-2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

 

  • CRAB criteria for MM
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin - It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17 pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium levels: Elevated calcium levels are part of the CRAB criteria and indicate disease activity, but are not as strong a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine: Increased serum creatinine is also part of the CRAB criteria and indicates renal involvement, but it is not the single most powerful predictor.

 

Option D. Protein levels: Protein levels can be elevated due to monoclonal proteins produced by myeloma cells, but again, they are not as powerful a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text: How many stages are described in Elisabeth Kübler-Ross model of 'coping with dying'? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Five

 

Explanation:

 

The Elisabeth Kübler-Ross model outlines five stages of grief. These stages were based on her work with terminally ill patients, though they have since been applied more broadly to anyone experiencing loss.

 

The five stages are:

 

 

These stages are not necessarily linear, and individuals may cycle through them in various orders or revisit stages over time.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Three: Some alternative models of grief suggest three phases (e.g., acute grief, integrated grief, and recovery), but this is not part of Kübler-Ross’s framework.
  • Option B. Four: While simplified adaptations might omit or combine stages, the original Kübler-Ross model contains five clearly defined stages.
  • Option D. Six: Some later interpretations have proposed a sixth stage (like "finding meaning", as suggested by David Kessler), but the classic Kübler-Ross model includes only five.

 

Educational Objective:


The Kübler-Ross model remains a foundational framework in understanding grief and loss, consisting of five stages denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance though experiences of grief are highly individual and not always stage-based.

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-sense mutation

 

Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Codons mutation: There are specific codons known as "stop codons" that signal the termination of protein synthesis. These stop codons include UAA, UAG, and UGA. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it releases the newly synthesized protein, and protein synthesis comes to an end.

 

Option C. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties.

 

Option D. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein.    

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 396

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve

 

The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:

 

  1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
  2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
  3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibers to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
  4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
  5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

 

Other marked structures:

 

  • 1- Optic nerve
  • 2- Abducent nerve
  • 4- Vestibulo cochlear nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve (II): The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is purely sensory in function. It begins at the retina, passes through the optic canal of the sphenoid bone, and joins the optic nerve of the opposite side at the optic chiasm. At this junction, fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross over.  Damage to the optic nerve can result in vision loss. Glaucoma, a condition with increased intraocular pressure, can damage the optic nerve and lead to blindness.

 

Option B. Abducent Nerve (VI): This nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally). It originates in the pons of the brainstem and travels through the superior orbital fissure to reach the orbit. Damage to this nerve can result in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a condition called lateral rectus palsy. This can manifest as double vision (diplopia) when looking to the side.

 

Option D. Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII): It has two parts: the cochlear nerve (for hearing) and the vestibular nerve (for balance). It originates in the inner ear and enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. Damage can lead to issues like sensorineural hearing loss or balance disorders like vertigo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trigeminal Nerve (V) is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions. Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing). 

 

It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).

 

The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets. 

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: Scenario with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characters present, uterus and ovaries present with an image as shown. What is the likely karyotype? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 46 XX

 

The scenario describes a patient with primary amenorrhea, secondary sexual characteristics, and a presence of the uterus and ovaries. The image shows an obstruction in the vaginal opening, which is likely an imperforate hymen. The presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal internal reproductive organs, such as the uterus and ovaries, indicates that the chromosomal pattern is normal female, 46 XX. The karyotype is not affected by the physical obstruction causing the amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 45 XO: This karyotype is characteristic of Turner syndrome, where patients usually have streak ovaries, lack secondary sexual characteristics, and have other distinct features like webbed neck and short stature, none of which are present in this scenario.

 

Option C. 47 XXY: This karyotype corresponds to Klinefelter syndrome, typically found in males who present with hypogonadism, tall stature, and often gynecomastia. It is not applicable to the described scenario with a female presentation.

 

Option D. 46 XY: This karyotype is associated with male individuals or conditions like Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. The presence of normal female internal reproductive structures (uterus and ovaries) rules out 46 XY.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics and intact internal female reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) generally indicates a normal female karyotype, 46 XX.
